origin: Late Middle English from Old French triumphe (noun), from Latin triump(h)us, probably from Greek thriambos ‘hymn to Bacchus’. Current senses of the verb date from the early 16th century.

definitions.example: a garden built to celebrate Napoleon's many triumphs

definitions.definition: The processional entry of a victorious general into ancient Rome.
definitions.example: Such was the fate of the Vandal king, Gelimir, paraded through Constantinople in 534 in a procession evoking the triumphs of ancient Rome.
spectacle has once again triumphed over content

definitions.definition: (of a Roman general) ride into ancient Rome after a victory.
definitions.example: Caesar triumphed at Rome four times in the same month, with a few days between each triumph.
